#Text=Liberian ex-President Charles Taylor convicted in war crimes trial
#Text=Thursday , April 26 , 2012
#Text=Former President of Liberia Charles Taylor was today found guilty of aiding and abetting war crimes by the Special Court for Sierra Leone in The Hague , Netherlands .
#Text=Taylor was acquitted of actually ordering the offences or being part of a joint enterprise to conduct them .
#Text=A school destroyed by RUF rebels .
#Text=Image : Laura Lartigue .

#Text=The eleven-count indictment produced a four-year trial that heard allegations of rape , murder , sexual slavery , cannibalism , arms dealing , " blood " diamond trade , and use of child soldiers .

column1: #Text=Prosecution witnesses totalled 94 whilst the defence had 21 including the accused .
#Text=Taylor spent his seven months of evidence claiming he was a peacemaker .
#Text=The allegations date to civil war in Sierra Leone , which ran from 1991 to 2002 .
#Text=Taylor , who had been a warlord since the ' 80s , backed the rebel Revolutionary United Front ( RUF ) .
#Text=Taylor was elected Liberian president in 1997 after a different civil war concluded .
#Text=Six years later he was ousted when an arrest warrant was issued and fled to Nigeria .
#Text=He was arrested there in 2006 whilst again trying to flee .
#Text=Taylor , who had been facing a rebellion against him since 1999 in Liberia , had received training from Libyan ruler Colonel Muammar Gaddafi ' s regime .
#Text=Testimony included claims that Taylor-backed fighters adorned roads with human intestines and ate human flesh .
#Text=One claimed to have seen Taylor himself eat human liver , something Taylor denied .
#Text=One described asking RUF rebels to sever his only hand in exchange for his young son 's life .
#Text=Further allegations said teenage children were involved in the fighting and that Taylor sold illegally mined diamonds to finance arms purchases for the RUF .
#Text=Western celebrities Naomi Campbell , a model , and Mia Farrow , an actress , described an incident at a charity dinner held by Nelson Mandella , then South Africa ' s head , in 1997 .
#Text=Campbell and Farrow said Taylor gifted Campbell a number of diamonds .
#Text=Taylor is claimed to have ordered seizure of Sierra Leone 's diamond deposits by RUF soldiers .
#Text=It was claimed in court that child soldiers were used in conflict , as diamond mine guards , and to carry out amputations .
#Text=Allegations of forced amputation were made .
#Text=The court , which has spent a year considering its verdicts , unanimously found Taylor guilty .
#Text=It ruled Taylor knew at least from 1997 the full extent of RUF activities in Sierra Leone , and that he helped bankroll activities dealing in blood diamonds .
#Text=A judge said more than a thousand youngsters had ' RUF ' carved into their skin to prevent escape .
#Text=From the moment he receives the full judgement Taylor has two weeks in which to file an appeal .
#Text=Human Rights Watch

#Text=and Amnesty International welcomed the verdict , which is the first conviction of a head of state before an international court since the Nuremburg trials prosecuted Nazi leaders after World War Two .
#Text=Karl Dönitz
#Text=was convicted after he took brief control of Germany in the aftermath of Adolf Hitler ' s suicide .
#Text=Former President of Yugoslavia Slobodan Milosevic faced trial but died before a judgement was handed down .
#Text=Laurent Gbagbo
#Text=, once Presldent of the Ivory Coast , is in custody at The Hague awaiting trial before the International Criminal Court .
#Text=Taylor joins eight other Special Court convicts , all of whom are from Sierra Leone .
#Text=He is the first African ruler to appear in The Hague .
#Text=The Special Court was formed jointly by Sierra Leone 's present administration and the United Nations .
#Text=The Netherlands agreed the process could be held there on the condition Taylor did not serve sentence there if convicted .
#Text=He is expected to be sent to the UK , where Foreign Office has promised to uphold an agreement to imprison him there made by ex-Foreign Secretary Margaret Beckett .
